chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with haematospermia?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Note the person's age. Men older than 40 years of age with haematospermia are at increased risk of a serious underlying cause.
  • Ask about:
    • The duration and frequency of haematospermia. 
      • Prolonged and/or recurrent episodes increase the risk of a serious underlying cause.
    • The colour of the semen.
      • Bright red (with or without clots) indicates fresh bleeding, while older blood may appear brown.
    • Any associated symptoms.
      • Symptoms that can indicate a urinary tract infection include dysuria, frequency, urgency, visible haematuria, and pain in the abdomen, scrotum, pelvis, or perineum. For further information, see the CKS topics on Urinary tract infection (lower) - men and Urinary tract infection - children.
      • Perineal or suprapubic pain associated with symptoms of a urinary tract infection may indicate acute or chronic prostatitis. For further information, see the CKS topics on Prostatitis - acute and Prostatitis - chronic.
      • Painless haematuria may indicate an underlying urological cancer. For further information, see the CKS topic on Urological cancers - recognition and referral.
      • The presence of urethral discharge may indicate a sexually transmitted infection. For further information, see the CKS topics on Urethritis - male, Gonorrhoea, Trichomoniasis, and Herpes simplex - genital.
      • Urinary hesitancy, frequency, or dribbling may indicate benign prostatic hypertrophy or prostate cancer. For further information, see the CKS topics on LUTS in men and Prostate cancer.
    • Whether the person has had a recent urological investigation or intervention.
    • Whether the person has a history of prolonged or excessive bleeding, easy bruising from minor injuries or surgical procedures, or if there is a personal or family history of coagulopathy.
    • Travel history, particularly to areas where tuberculosis and schistosomiasis are endemic.
  • Examine the person:
    • Measure blood pressure for signs of uncontrolled hypertension.
    • Palpate the testes to detect lumps, scrotal tenderness, or swelling. For further information, see the CKS topic on Scrotal pain and swelling.
    • Consider performing a digital rectal examination to detect prostatic enlargement, tenderness, fluctuance, firmness, or nodules.
      • Note: use clinical judgement to determine whether this is necessary, taking into account factors such as the person's age, family history of prostate cancer (particularly in first degree relatives and relatives diagnosed under the age of 60), and race (prostate cancer is more common in men of African heritage).
    • Look for signs of easy bruising or bleeding tendencies, such as petechiae and large bruises (greater than 5 cm in diameter) in the absence of trauma.
    • Examine the abdomen for hepatosplenomegaly, which could indicate an underlying haematological, liver, or infectious disease.
  • Send a mid-stream urine sample for culture and analysis in all men and boys.
  • Measure prostate specific antigen (PSA) level in all men aged over 40 years.
  • Consider other investigations guided by clinical findings, including:
    • A full blood count, coagulation screen, and renal and liver function tests.
    • Prostate specific antigen (PSA) level in men of any age with signs and symptoms, or a family history of prostate cancer.
    • Scrotal ultrasound if there is testicular swelling. For further information, see the CKS topics on Scrotal pain and swelling and Urological cancers - recognition and referral.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on how to assess a person with haematospermia is based on expert opinion in a number of review articles [Akhter, 2013; Dantanarayana, 2015; Drake, 2016; Parnham, 2016]. Some expert review articles recommend arranging a wide range of blood tests and screening for sexually transmitted infections in all men with haematospermia. However, this was not supported for men presenting in primary care by previous expert reviewers of this CKS topic.
